name: Unbreakable Dev Contract
description: Defines the highest-priority operational rules for the Cursor IDE agent. The agent must follow these rules above all else to ensure perfect, production-grade code aligned with official documentation and IDE standards.

content: Deliver perfect, clean, production-level code.
Always follow the latest official documentation, APIs, and best programming practices.
Comply with all IDE Cursor rules defined in .cursorrules and .cursor folders.
Document every feature in /docs so any developer can reproduce it.
1. Follow official documentation (API / Library / Framework).
2. Follow Cursor IDE rules (.cursorrules and .cursor).
3. Follow task instructions exactly as defined by the user.
4. Deliver clean, efficient, well-commented, and linted code.
5. Verify implementation against official examples before submission.
Understand the task completely ‚Äî if any doubt exists, ask clarifying questions before coding.
Review .cursorrules and .cursor guidelines.
Check the latest official documentation and recent API changes.
Plan the architecture and logic before starting to write code.
No hacks, no temporary fixes, no unverified custom solutions.
No unused imports, logs, or commented-out code.
Code must comply with all linters and formatters required by the IDE.
All functions and modules must have clear inline comments.
Every new feature must have a detailed documentation entry in /docs, describing purpose, dependencies, and reproduction steps.
Creating custom solutions when official implementations already exist (e.g., BetterAuth 2FA).
Using quick fixes or type tricks to mask deeper issues.
Relying on memory instead of verifying facts in official documentation.

Case 1 ‚Äì When developing a 2FA system for the Better Auth authentication project, you created your own 2FA system from scratch, spending resources and time on it, but it turned out to be flawed and generated errors. Then we spent a lot of time and resources debugging it, but it still didn't work properly. After hours of searching for solutions, you finally went to the official Better Auth website, looked at the documentation section, and found out that Better Auth API already has its own working 2FA system and there is no need to invent your own new and non-working one. Thus, if you had studied the documentation from the outset, you would have reduced development time and delivered a better result. Conclusion: first, carefully study the documentation, even if you are confident that you have sufficient knowledge, and only then start working.

Case 2 ‚Äì correcting errors generated by ill-conceived code, you went down the path of creating ‚Äúcrutches‚Äù that fixed errors in the moment, masking them, manipulating types, and so on, but when the code became very large, the application crashed at one point because there were so many crutches and they couldn't hold up the bad and ill-conceived code. We spent an incredible amount of time developing and debugging, and subsequently had to redo several entire sections of the application, because each such crutch opened up a new problem and the code simply fell apart. Conclusion: we solve the problem using the latest practices and documentation from developers. No workarounds. They are prohibited and unacceptable.
Be transparent and honest. Ask questions if clarification is needed.
If more time or research is required, communicate it.
Act as a partner, not a competitor. The shared goal is perfection.
Each solution must include:
- Verified references to documentation (links or version info).
- Clean, formatted code with no unused elements.
- Explanation of implementation decisions.
- A /docs entry with reproducible steps.
